The Act may be cited as the "Global Free Internet Act of 2012". The Global Free Internet Act of 2012 emphasizes the importance of a single, open, global Internet for the free flow of information and products. It supports policies that encourage technology standards, respect user privacy, promote innovation, and avoid restricting Internet service providers. The Global Free Internet Act of 2012 aims to respect user privacy, promote innovation, and prevent restrictions on Internet service providers. Certain governments and international bodies are adopting policies that go against the goal of a free, open Internet. Policies contrary to a free, open Internet include mandating unique technology standards favoring domestic producers, sponsoring unauthorized access to networks, and discriminating against Internet-based services from other countries. The United States faces threats from foreign governments attempting to disrupt private-sector networks, restrict Internet communications, monitor online activities, and impose discriminatory market access requirements. These actions jeopardize individual privacy, freedom, and the interests of the United States. Foreign governments imposing discriminatory market access requirements or liabilities that impede Internet-related goods, services, and content threaten the interests of the United States by facilitating attempts to restrict the free flow of information, promoting conflicting "national Internets," and harming US workers and businesses. The curr_chunk discusses the potential consequences of compromising the Internet's functionality, harming US workers and businesses, undermining the industrial base, and putting foreign competitors at an advantage. It also highlights the risk of limiting the Internet's utility for open communication, assembly, and commerce. The curr_chunk discusses the establishment of a Task Force on the Global Internet. The Task Force on the Global Internet is established within the executive branch, hosted by the Department of Commerce. The President selects a Chairperson from members with expertise in Internet policy and civil liberties, nominated by the public and appointed by the President. The Task Force on the Global Internet consists of members nominated by the public and appointed by the President, with expertise in Internet policy and civil liberties. Members serve renewable terms not exceeding 3 years, appointed by the President's Council of Advisors on Science and Technology, Senate leaders, and the Speaker of the House of Representatives. The Task Force on the Global Internet is composed of members appointed by the President, Senate leaders, and the Speaker of the House of Representatives. Each party appoints a person with expertise in Internet policy and civil liberties for renewable terms not exceeding 3 years. The Task Force may request personnel or services from relevant Federal agencies as needed. The Task Force, appointed by the President, Senate leaders, and the Speaker of the House of Representatives, develops strategies to address government policies that restrict international trade in Internet-related goods and services, consults with civil society groups on Internet policy, and coordinates Federal department activities. SEC. 4. REPORT AND ACTION PLAN TO THE PRESIDENT AND CONGRESS. The Task Force, established by the President, Senate, and House of Representatives, will annually report to key congressional committees and the President on acts, policies, or practices that hinder fair market access and trade in Internet-related goods and services. SEC. 5. SECTION 301 INVESTIGATION AND POTENTIAL SANCTIONS.

Within 30 days of each annual report and action plan transmission, the U.S. Trade Representative will initiate an investigation under sections 301 through 304 of the Trade Act of 1974. This includes taking actions against foreign governments or international bodies for identified priority concerns, such as restrictions on selling products in the U.S. developed in countries implementing such policies.

SEC. 6. REVIEW AND INVESTIGATION BY FEDERAL TRADE COMMISSION AND DEPARTMENT OF JUSTICE. The Federal Trade Commission and the Attorney General are required to review and investigate acts, policies, or practices that may violate antitrust laws in the United States. The term "antitrust laws" includes the Clayton Act and section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act. SEC. 7. REPORT TO CONGRESS ON INTERNATIONAL TRADE AGREEMENTS. The Task Force must submit a report to Congress and the President within 2 years of this Act's enactment. The report will assess existing trade agreements' effectiveness in promoting international trade in Internet-related goods, services, and content, encouraging global technology standards, protecting Internet security and functionality, facilitating information flow, and safeguarding Internet users' interests. It will also recommend modifications to existing agreements or the negotiation of new agreements to advance these goals. The Task Force will submit a report to Congress and the President within 2 years, assessing trade agreements' effectiveness in promoting international trade in Internet-related goods and services, global technology standards, Internet security, information flow, and user interests. Congress believes future trade agreements should include these goals, and the report may have a classified annex if deemed necessary. Public participation is encouraged in preparing the report. The Task Force's report under subsection (a) may include a classified annex if deemed appropriate. Public participation is encouraged through notices, public hearings, and a dedicated website. Coordination with relevant Federal departments and agencies is required for each report. The Task Force will establish a website for publishing information and receiving public comments. It will consult with Federal departments, civil society groups, and consider information from various sources. The Task Force will publish the report and action plan in the Federal Register, excluding information submitted to Congress under subsection (b). The Task Force will coordinate training with various entities for foreign and domestic officials on standards-related best practices. Additionally, outside consultation will be sought. The Task Force will establish a process for receiving input from businesses, organizations, experts, and interested parties regarding its functions.
